page.title: 01BIRDLIFE ON MARK MOOR
page.content: Waders this is said to be part of the best breeding area in the S.W.Lapwings in large flocks are a common sight in autumn feeding in the fields. Curlews, redshank & snipe are frequently heard & sometimes seen. Garden birds many species appear the year long including woodpeckers searching lawns for ants. Residents in holes in willows bordering rhynes are redstarts, treesparrows & little owls, sometimes mallards.Mute swans nest on rhyne banks. Herons stand motionless or flap silently up & down the waterways searching for food. Migrants from Africa are yellow wagtails, whinchats & sedgewarblers. From the north come plovers, redwings, fieldfares & many wildfowl. Most impressive are large flocks of Bewick swans feeding on the early grass.
